txt.en: 'A single warrior and the old laws of mercy upheld.'
'Although I doubted something in Claghórd's words, Crannog accepted.'
'I stepped forward to fight for the Trév Gállorg and awaited Crannog's command.'
'A man named Sácharth crept forward and begged to fight for the Trév Duvárdain.'
'But it did not matter. The Trév Duvárdain were victorious.'
Instance: The Rite Undone
'Never had I imagined that a man worse than Domongart could lead the Trév Duvárdain.'
'I was wrong.'
'I was to fight against Sácharth, or so I thought.'
'As if in answer, Claghórd himself stepped forward, passing Sácharth without a word.'
'In truth, Claghórd had chosen to fight for the Trév Duvárdain long before he arrived at Fail-á-Khro.'
'And again, without a word, he had also chosen who would fight for the Trév Gállorg...'
'Crannog.'
'For a chieftain to shrink from another chieftain's challenge would be unthinkable.'
'But Claghórd was a younger man by far, and he knew what this would mean for the coming fight.'
'And so, Crannog led us to Fail-á-Khro to meet the Trév Duvárdain in Clúcath.'
'And so, the rite of Clúcath began.'
'Leading the Trév Duvárdain was their chieftain, Claghórd.'
'Crannog fought well, but it was not long before he was forced to yield.'
'It was said that Domongart, their chieftain of old, had been cast out.'
'Even though they had held to the tenets of the rite, Claghórd had acted beneath the dignity of a chieftain.'
'Whatever the reason for Domongart's exile, the Trév Duvárdain who now followed Claghórd remained faithful servants of the Iron Crown.'
'After a long silence, Claghórd spoke and offered his terms for Clúcath.'
